Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Using nanoparticle biosensors to observe molecular DNA changes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Personalized medicine is a medical model that the healthcare community is actively striving to achieve. Related to personalized care are technologies that allow affordable and efficient access to a patient's unique molecular characteristics (i.e genetic distinctions). This research will lead to the development of a nanoparticle based biosensor which observes changes in genetic material, such as DNA, under simulated environments. Understanding the behavior of biomolecules is important in determining their functions. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Kang Wang, responsible for a dark-field microscopy system, a vital component for the proposed sensor, at Nanjing University in China.

The aforementioned microscopy system is a single particle scattering spectroscopy system consisting of a dark-field microscope mounted with a spectroscopy unit and a charge-coupled device (CCD). This system can observe the scattering spectroscopy of nanoparticles. The scattering spectroscopy of these nanoparticles can vary based on biorecognition reactions and their ability to cause a change in the dielectric constant on the nanoparticle surface. The proposed research explores this phenomenon further by looking at conformational changes that occur in nanoparticle-tethered- DNA sequences under stimulated environments and determining the effects of these changes on the dielectric constant of the nanoparticle. Being able to observe a change in the dieletric constant will lead to the development of a system which characterizes conformational changes of DNA, thus a nanoprobe for detecting micro-environments in living cells that will provide greater signal intensity than conventional fluorescence probes. This system would be useful to researches looking for an analysis technique that would characterize microprocesses of several types (e.g., metabolism of cells or the corrosion of metals). This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aim. Personalized medicine is a medical model that the healthcare community is actively striving to achieve. Related to personalized care are technologies that allow affordable and efficient access to a patient’s unique molecular characteristics (i.e genetic distinctions). The completed research has laid the foundation for the development of a single gold nanoparticle (AuNP) based biosensor which observes conformational changes in genetic material such as DNA under simulated environments (e.g. applied potentials). Understanding conformational behavior of biomolecules is important in determining their functions. 

Results. We successfully observed spectral shifts of localized plasmon resonance scattering of changing confirmations of DNA modified on AuNPs, which untimately has the potential to lead to a biosensor that can determine the conformation of DNA and other nucleic acids. Localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) is characterized as the oscillation of electrons induced by incident light. The resonance (i.e oscillation) is induced when the frequency of the light photons is identical to that of the surface electrons of the liquid or solid of interest. That frequency is thought to change based on physical and chemical changes that can occur to the material and its environment. With this particular research we were able to detect slight changes based on the change in conformation of DNA with changes also occurring as the environment is changed. 

Once we were able to obtain an understanding of how changes in the environment may or may not affect a spectral shift, using high ionic strengths, we immobilized a single stranded DNA sequence (ssDNA) on the surface of the AuNP. As a result we observed another spectral shift, confirming the immobilization of the nucleic acid on the surface

An electric potential of -0.3V was then applied to the surface. Due to the molecule's charged nature, the conformation of the ssDNA on the surface of the AuNP was expected to go from a compact formation in close proximity to the surface to one that is extended upright away from the surface. Spectral shifts captured this conformational change. It appears that the initial spectrum of the DNA-AuNP has undergone a slight blue (left) shift once a potential has been applied (shifts brought upon by applied potential were subtracted from the final spectrum). Ultimately, we were able to combine dark field imaging and NPPR to slightly observe conformational changes of DNA on single AuNPs. 

Intellectual Merit. The dark field microscopy device is unique to the Xia Research Group at Nanjing University, thus ensuring the originality of the proposed analysis technique. Successful observation of induced spectrum change on single nanoparticle has the potential to lead to the development of a nanoprobe that would allow for the characterization of a variety of micro-processes, for example, those influenced by changes in pH (e.g., metabolism of cells or the corrosion of metals). Contrary to conventional probes, this system has the potential to provide a stronger read-out signal with greater stability.My research background in biotechnologies and surface based chemistries; more specifically those involving morpholino (MO), a neutral nucleic acid mimic, on solid surfaces, qualifies me to conduct the proposed research. Additionally, my host, Dr. Kang Wang, completed a post doc in my current research group and traces of his work can be seen in the Xia Research Group; therefore, providing the opportunity to foster a mutually beneficial research goal based on commonalities in projects at our respective labs.
